articles.headline: Mindful of Bubbles in a Boom for Deals
articles.snippet: There have been over a thousand mergers and buyouts in the first months of 2013, leading some to wonder if the markets are overvalued.
articles.abstract: There have been over a thousand mergers and buyouts in the first months of 2013, leading some to wonder if the markets are overvalued.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett has teamed up with 3G Capital to buy the venerable H. J. Heinz Company for $23 billion. But the famed value investor isn’t exactly buying low: when the deal was announced on Valentine’s Day, Heinz shares were trading at a record high of nearly $61. Had Mr. Buffett and his partners bought a year ago, shares were selling for $53, a 13 percent discount.

articles.headline: White House Uses Air Delays as Budget Prod
articles.snippet: The focus on disruptions if spending cuts take effect showed that the Obama administration believed that the threat of widespread travel problems could force Republicans to the bargaining table.
articles.abstract: The focus on disruptions if spending cuts take effect showed that the Obama administration believed that the threat of widespread travel problems could force Republicans to the bargaining table.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday warned of potentially severe disruptions in air travel if across-the-board spending cuts take effect in less than a week as President Obama intensified pressure on Congressional Republicans to entertain spending reductions and tax increases to avoid furloughing federal workers and limiting services.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Patron of Siena Stumbles
articles.snippet: Nowhere are Monte dei Paschi’s problems more acutely felt than in Siena. The bank has paid for charitable and civic works for as long as anyone can remember.
articles.abstract: Nowhere are Monte dei Paschi’s problems more acutely felt than in Siena. The bank has paid for charitable and civic works for as long as anyone can remember.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIENA, Italy — Cut into the stonework of the imposing Palazzo Salimbeni is a name that has been entwined with the fortunes of this Tuscan city for five centuries: Monte dei Paschi, or Mount of the Pastures.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Gaia Pianigiani

articles.headline: In Paid Family Leave, U.S. Trails Most of the Globe
articles.snippet: The United States has among the world’s worst leave laws for new parents or for tending to a sick child, prompting some family advocates to seek an overhaul of the rules.
articles.abstract: The United States has among the world’s worst leave laws for new parents or for tending to a sick child, prompting some family advocates to seek an overhaul of the rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: There I was, on the day my six months of maternity leave had ended, pushing my son’s stroller with one hand, clutching a jumbo box of 174 diapers with the other, doing my best to navigate through piles of slushy snow.

articles.headline: No Exit: China Uses Passports as Political Cudgel
articles.snippet: People who speak out against the government as well as members of minority groups are often barred from leaving or re-entering.
articles.abstract: People who speak out against the government as well as members of minority groups are often barred from leaving or re-entering.

articles.headline: Pentagon Orders F-35 Jets Grounded
articles.snippet: Flights by the stealthy jets, being delivered to all three branches of the military, were suspended after an inspection found a crack in a turbine blade on a test plane.
articles.abstract: Flights by the stealthy jets, being delivered to all three branches of the military, were suspended after an inspection found a crack in a turbine blade on a test plane.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon said on Friday that it had grounded all of its stealthy new F-35 fighter jets after an inspection found a crack in a turbine blade in the engine of one of the planes.

articles.headline: HTC Settles Privacy Case Over Flaws in Phones
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission charged HTC with customizing software on its phones in ways that could steal personal information and surreptitiously send text messages.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission charged HTC with customizing software on its phones in ways that could steal personal information and surreptitiously send text messages.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 18 million smartphones and other mobile devices made by HTC, a Taiwanese company that is one of the largest sellers of smartphones in the United States, had security flaws that could allow location tracking of users against their will and the theft of personal information stored on their phones, federal officials said Friday.

articles.headline: Catholics Gather in California, Haunted by Cardinal’s Scandal
articles.snippet: At the Religious Education Congress in Los Angeles, the nation’s largest annual gathering of Roman Catholics, many have been re-evaluating Cardinal Roger M. Mahony’s legacy.
articles.abstract: At the Religious Education Congress in Los Angeles, the nation’s largest annual gathering of Roman Catholics, many have been re-evaluating Cardinal Roger M. Mahony’s legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — For decades, Cardinal Roger M. Mahony was the convener and the star of the nation’s largest annual gathering of Roman Catholics, which opened here on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Obama’s Backers Seek Big Donors to Press Agenda
articles.snippet: President Obama’s political team is attempting to raise $50 million to convert his re-election campaign into a powerhouse lobbying group for his second-term goals.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s political team is attempting to raise $50 million to convert his re-election campaign into a powerhouse lobbying group for his second-term goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s political team is fanning out across the country in pursuit of an ambitious goal: raising $50 million to convert his re-election campaign into a powerhouse national advocacy network, a sum that would rank the new group as one of Washington’s biggest lobbying operations.

articles.headline: Fear of U.S. Cuts Grows in States Where Aid Flows
articles.snippet: State officials fear that the budget impasse in Washington will saddle them with spending cuts that threaten to slow their recoveries or thrust them back into recession.
articles.abstract: State officials fear that the budget impasse in Washington will saddle them with spending cuts that threaten to slow their recoveries or thrust them back into recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: States are increasingly alarmed that they could become collateral damage in Washington’s latest fiscal battle, fearing that the impasse could saddle them with across-the-board spending cuts that threaten to slow their fragile recoveries or thrust them back into recession.

articles.headline: Don’t Call Him Mom, or an Imbecile
articles.snippet: The hapless, bumbling father is a stock character in product marketing. The so-called daddy bloggers who attended the recent Dad 2.0 Summit are pushing to change that.
articles.abstract: The hapless, bumbling father is a stock character in product marketing. The so-called daddy bloggers who attended the recent Dad 2.0 Summit are pushing to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE hapless, bumbling father is a stock character in product marketing. He makes breakfast for dinner and is incapable of handling, or sometimes even noticing, a soggy diaper. He tries desperately to hide the crumb-strewn, dirt-streaked evidence of his poor parenting before the mother gets home.

articles.headline: Dell’s Intentions Get a Hard Look
articles.snippet: Outside shareholders who support an independent analysis of the company’s value are wary of dealings by Michael Dell that may take the business private.
articles.abstract: Outside shareholders who support an independent analysis of the company’s value are wary of dealings by Michael Dell that may take the business private.
articles.lead_paragraph: IS Michael Dell trying to take over the computer company he founded on the cheap?

articles.headline: High Debt and Falling Demand Trap New Vets
articles.snippet: The cost of veterinarian school has far outpaced the rate of inflation. Meanwhile, there is a boom in supply (that is, vets), and a decline in demand for services.
articles.abstract: The cost of veterinarian school has far outpaced the rate of inflation. Meanwhile, there is a boom in supply (that is, vets), and a decline in demand for services.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAYLEY SCHAFER chose her dream job at the age of 5. Three years later, her grandmother told her that if she wrote it down, the dream would come true. So she found a piece of blue construction paper and scrawled on it with a pencil: “Veterianian.” “No one told me how to spell it,” she remembers. “They just said, ‘Sound it out.’ ”

articles.headline: Major Banks Aid in Payday Loans Banned by States
articles.snippet: Banking giants have become behind-the-scenes allies of Internet-based lenders that offer loans with interest rates that can exceed 500 percent.
articles.abstract: Banking giants have become behind-the-scenes allies of Internet-based lenders that offer loans with interest rates that can exceed 500 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major banks have quickly become behind-the-scenes allies of Internet-based payday lenders that offer short-term loans with interest rates sometimes exceeding 500 percent.

articles.headline: Swollen With Syrian Refugees, Lebanon Feels Its Stitching Fray
articles.snippet: An influx of needy Syrians, seeming to fill Lebanon’s every nook and cranny, is heightening sectarian tensions in a nation haunted by refugee crises and loath to act.
articles.abstract: An influx of needy Syrians, seeming to fill Lebanon’s every nook and cranny, is heightening sectarian tensions in a nation haunted by refugee crises and loath to act.
articles.lead_paragraph: QAA, Lebanon — Quietly but inexorably, a human tide has crept into Lebanon, Syria’s smallest and most vulnerable neighbor.

articles.headline: Fault-Finding Grows Intense as Cuts Near
articles.snippet: With less than a week before what was once unthinkable — deep across-the-board spending cuts — both the White House and Congress are eager to say sequestration was the other’s idea.
articles.abstract: With less than a week before what was once unthinkable — deep across-the-board spending cuts — both the White House and Congress are eager to say sequestration was the other’s idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — First the White House and Congress created a potential fiscal crisis, agreeing more than a year ago to once-unthinkable governmentwide spending cuts in 2013 unless the two parties agreed to alternative ways to reduce budget deficits.

articles.headline: A Conservative Provocateur, Using a Blowtorch as His Pen
articles.snippet: Michael Goldfarb, a founder of a conservative online magazine called The Washington Free Beacon, has combined journalism, politicking and campaign finance into a potent mix.
articles.abstract: Michael Goldfarb, a founder of a conservative online magazine called The Washington Free Beacon, has combined journalism, politicking and campaign finance into a potent mix.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 11:42 a.m. on Feb. 14, a conservative online magazine called The Washington Free Beacon posted a dispatch about a speech Chuck Hagel gave in 2007 in which it said he called the State Department “an adjunct to the Israeli foreign minister’s office.”

articles.headline: Afghanistan Bars Elite U.S. Troops From a Key Province
articles.snippet: Officials cited complaints that Afghans working for American Special Forces had killed and tortured villagers in a strategically important province adjoining Kabul.
articles.abstract: Officials cited complaints that Afghans working for American Special Forces had killed and tortured villagers in a strategically important province adjoining Kabul.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government barred elite American forces from operating in a strategic province adjoining Kabul on Sunday, citing complaints that Afghans working for American Special Operations forces had tortured and killed villagers in the area.

articles.headline: For Stocks, an Upturn Is Battered by Doubts
articles.snippet: After looking ready to rocket past milestone levels just a few weeks ago, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is coming out of its first negative week of 2013.
articles.abstract: After looking ready to rocket past milestone levels just a few weeks ago, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index is coming out of its first negative week of 2013.
articles.lead_paragraph: The investor euphoria that began the year is beginning to seem like a hazy dream.

articles.headline: In Cyberspace, New Cold War
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is escalating demands that China halt the state-sponsored computer hack attacks that Beijing insists it is not mounting.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is escalating demands that China halt the state-sponsored computer hack attacks that Beijing insists it is not mounting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration circulated to the nation’s Internet providers last week a lengthy confidential list of computer addresses linked to a hacking group that has stolen terabytes of data from American corporations, it left out one crucial fact: that nearly every one of the digital addresses could be traced to the neighborhood in Shanghai that is headquarters to the Chinese military’s cybercommand.

articles.headline: Giving Viewers What They Want
articles.snippet: In any business, the ability to see into the future is the killer app, and Netflix may be getting close with “House of Cards.”
articles.abstract: In any business, the ability to see into the future is the killer app, and Netflix may be getting close with “House of Cards.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In the television business, there is no such thing as a sure thing. You can have a gold-plated director, a bankable star and a popular concept and still, it’s just a roll of the dice.

articles.headline: Turks Debate Modest Dress Set for Takeoff
articles.snippet: Proposed new uniforms for Turkish Airlines flight attendants, including long dresses and Ottoman-style fez caps, have created an uproar over how the flagship carrier should be perceived.
articles.abstract: Proposed new uniforms for Turkish Airlines flight attendants, including long dresses and Ottoman-style fez caps, have created an uproar over how the flagship carrier should be perceived.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — When flight attendants first rode aboard Turkish Airlines in the late 1940s they wore cotton blouses under blue suits tailored to accentuate “the contours of the body,” as a fashion history of the airline puts it. In the ’60s and ’70s the trend continued with fashions straight off the Paris runway, designed to show Turkey’s European flair on its flagship airline.

articles.headline: Lack of Backup Power Puts Cruise Passengers at the Ocean’s Mercy
articles.snippet: Nearly all cruise ships lack backup systems to help a ship return to port should power fail because to install them would have cost operators more money.
articles.abstract: Nearly all cruise ships lack backup systems to help a ship return to port should power fail because to install them would have cost operators more money.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is becoming a familiar tale: When the cruise ship was towed into port, the endless hours for passengers of sleeping on deck and going without electricity or toilets were finally over.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and John Schwartz

articles.headline: In Turnabout, NBC Prime Time Lands in the Cellar
articles.snippet: As sweeps month nears its end, the network is struggling to recover from an embarrassing and potentially costly ratings plunge.
articles.abstract: As sweeps month nears its end, the network is struggling to recover from an embarrassing and potentially costly ratings plunge.
articles.lead_paragraph: With every passing week, the sudden blossoming of prime-time success that NBC experienced last fall is looking more like a mirage.

articles.headline: As BP Trial Opens, Hints of Progress on a Deal
articles.snippet: No one involved in the case has commented on any progress, but several lawyers briefed on the negotiations said that a $16 billion proposal had been made.
articles.abstract: No one involved in the case has commented on any progress, but several lawyers briefed on the negotiations said that a $16 billion proposal had been made.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — As the trial against BP stemming from the 2010 explosion of a drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico began here Monday morning, the details of a settlement offer by federal and state officials to the oil company to emerge.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Acceptance of Defense Cuts Signals Shift in G.O.P. Focus
articles.snippet: Republicans are now ready to stand their ground on spending cuts that will hit the military hard, underscoring what some say was a miscalculation on President Obama’s part.
articles.abstract: Republicans are now ready to stand their ground on spending cuts that will hit the military hard, underscoring what some say was a miscalculation on President Obama’s part.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Congress unlikely to stop deep automatic spending cuts that will strike hard at the military, the fiscal stalemate is highlighting a significant shift in the Republican Party: lawmakers most keenly dedicated to shrinking the size of government are now more dominant than the bloc committed foremost to a robust national defense, particularly in the House.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Twitter Hacking Puts Focus on Security for Brands
articles.snippet: With attacks on the Twitter accounts of Burger King, Jeep and others, the site’s relatively lax security is a concern.
articles.abstract: With attacks on the Twitter accounts of Burger King, Jeep and others, the site’s relatively lax security is a concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: While most Americans were winding up their holiday weekends last Monday, the phones at the Vancouver headquarters of HootSuite, a social media management company, began to ring.
articles.byline: By Tanzina Vega and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: ‘Bloodless’ Lung Transplants Offer Hint at Surgery’s Future
articles.snippet: Hospitals are working to further innovate “bloodless” operations, both to treat those who shun transfusions and to advance techniques that may be safer for all patients.
articles.abstract: Hospitals are working to further innovate “bloodless” operations, both to treat those who shun transfusions and to advance techniques that may be safer for all patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Last April, after being told that only a transplant could save her from a fatal lung condition, Rebecca S. Tomczak began calling some of the top-ranked hospitals in the country.

articles.headline: Crossed Paths: Chicago’s Jacksons and Obamas
articles.snippet: The ascent of the leading black political family in the United States is inextricable from the unraveling of an older one.
articles.abstract: The ascent of the leading black political family in the United States is inextricable from the unraveling of an older one.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Barack and Michelle Obamawere married in Chicago two decades ago, Santita Jackson, a daughter of the Rev.Jesse L. Jackson, sang at their wedding. When Mr. Obama ran for his first national office, he made sure he was not stepping on the ambitions of her brother,Jesse L. Jackson Jr., who later became a co-chairman of his 2008 presidential campaign.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Monica Davey
